These suggestions are quite rough and certainly need refining.
But they do indicate some of the possibilities which have been dis¬
cussed within the MEB Utilization Committee.
This problem breaks down into several phases. To do all of
these at once would require considerable money. Actually, the
first step would be to pin-point the needs and the supply of material.
A phase structure which might be followed is suggested here.
PHASE I - F.XPLORATQRY
The objectives of this phase would be to define the project,
locate areas of needs:, find examples of utilization, and orient
key people into the project. Specific utilization projects could
be worked out with the local station or organizations if they can
or will undertake the financing. The most practical and expedient
method of doing this would be by a personal visit to the various
locations. An itinerary for these visits can not b© worked out
until a preliminary approach has been made through correspondence.
Off hand, the points that appear most likely to come up with usable
material is Pittsburgh, Chicago, St» Louis, Boston, Philadelphia,
Haggerstown, Seattle, Ban Francisco, Sacramento, and Denver , I*m
sure that all of these could not be visited but a series of letters
should eliminate some. In meet instances, the areas mentioned have
both an educational radio and television station in operation.
Borne exchangeable material might result from these first visits.
However, the principle objective would be orientation, and the
development of a proposal to be made to either a foundation or the
U.S. Office of Health, Education, and Welfare.
